executive_summary: Once seen as a hobby, craft beer has transformed into one of the fastest-growing and most popular alcoholic beverage segments in the United States. However, the once-booming industry has reached a tipping point over the past decade, as oversaturation and the emergence of many substitutes have stalled revenue growth. The pandemic coincided with craft brewery's growth approaching normalization, resulting in a period of drastic volatility. Unlike some of its external competitors, craft breweries struggled to maintain consistent growth in the pandemic's wake. Thus, revenue has been sinking at a CAGR of 3.8% over the past five years and is estimated to fall 1.9% in 2024 alone, when revenue will reach $7.2 billion.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Produced Uncharacteristic Volatility for Craft Breweries
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, craft breweries were approaching saturation, with revenue growth tapering from the explosive highs of the industry's youth to more normalized growth. The pandemic and subsequent social-distancing measures, along with nonessential business closures, resulted in drastic disruptions for most craft brewers, as many rely on in-person sales and events to generate sales and spread word-of-mouth recommendations. Though revenue began rebounding as vaccines became widely available, the unprecedented circumstances caused shifts in consumer preferences and drinking habits, forcing many craft brewers to contend with a changed landscape.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile Conditions Do Little to Discourage New Entrants
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite a deceleration of the craft craze, new local and regional breweries have continued emerging to capitalize on what's left of the craft boom and try their hand in the field. While new craft brewers popped up at much greater rates in decades prior, more than 2,000 new craft breweries have opened since 2019, intensifying competition in an already crowded space.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A RETURN TO GROWTH IS ON THE HORIZON BUT AT A VASTLY SUBDUED RATE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite rising imports, domestic craft breweries typically have the advantage of attracting a loyal local following through community outreach and large events, a unique advantage that even larger domestic producers lack. Many craft brewers lack the means to effectively export products, due to the small production level requirements to be distinguished as a craft brewery, so exports account for a small share of revenue. Moving forward, craft breweries will manage a return to growth, capitalizing on emerging markets, but the explosive expansion once common to the industry is unlikely to return.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: COMPETITION FROM OTHER CRAFT BEVERAGES WILL INTENSIFY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Competition from alternative beverage producers, like distilleries, wineries, commercial breweries and other, nonalcoholic beverages, like kombucha and THC-infused beverages, is likely to rise substantially over the next five years. A trend toward premiumization, which will be fostered by rising disposable income levels, will encourage consumers to trade up to more expensive.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Largest Craft Breweries Will Get Bigger
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Only the largest craft breweries, like Boston Beer Company, have typically been able to complete effective and profitable mergers and acquisitions (M&A). However, in the coming years, as more craft breweries reach maturity and a crowded landscape renders organic growth difficult, M&A activity is likely to rise. Craft breweries operate in a unique environment: A craft brewery must produce less than 6.0 million barrels of beer each year, so growing too large results in the brewery losing its craft distinction, forcing owners to weigh the benefits of increasing production.

industry_definition: This industry includes microbreweries and brewpubs that produce beer for resale or consumption on premises. A microbrewery produces a limited amount of beer, typically no more than 6.0 million barrels (189,000,000 US gallons) of beer per year. A brewpub brews and sells beer on the premises and may prepare and serve food to dining patrons. A brewpub may also be considered a microbrewery if it engages in a significant amount of beer distribution on a regional level.
key_trends: Competition among craft brewers heats up as producers flood the market.
Ready-to-drink cocktails and hard seltzers are outpacing craft beer in popularity.
The craft craze is decelerating as consumers look to alternative beverages.
The US has made an international name for itself as a craft beer producer.
Boston Beer dominates craft beer production.
Yuengling expands its geographic footprint through a partnership with Coors.
The three-tier system keeps craft breweries small since it doesn't allow vertical integration between producers and wholesalers or retailers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The younger US population has historically been a key market for craft brewers as this age cohort prefers more diverse flavors, like craft IPAs, and largely grew up around the craft beer boom.
This segment includes drinkers between the ages of 35 and 54 who are largely responsible for ushering in the initial craft beer boom in the 90s.

This segment includes consumers aged 55 and older and tends to account for the smallest share of revenue generated by craft breweries but the segment has blossomed into an important market for brewers, capturing almost the same share of revenue as the youngest market segment.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment features India Pale Ales, a pale ale style renowned for its robust hop flavors that have become synonymous with the craft beer revolution.

This segment includes pale and amber ales. Pale ales are made using a high proportion of two-row pale malt, giving the beer a light color, while amber ales are a balance of caramelized and amber-hued malt that has been kilned longer to provide the beer with a richer flavor with a deeper, copper tinge.
This segment includes seasonal beers, which are limited-edition beers typically distributed at the start of a new season.
This segment includes wheat beer, a type of beer brewed with a substantial amount of wheat relative to malted barley.
This segment includes lagers and all other beer varieties like stouts and flavored malt beverages.
This segment includes sour and other fruit beers with acidic, sour or fruity flavors.

tier_1_suppliers: Wheat, Barley & Sorghum Farming in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Alcohol consumption patterns significantly impact craft beer sales. Factors such as consumer income, cultural preferences and personal tastes shape beer demand. Additionally, craft brewers vie with other alcoholic beverage producers for a share of consumers' spending on alcohol. When consumers boost their expenditure on alcoholic beverages, it presents potential opportunities for craft breweries.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Foreign Brewers Struggle to Compete with the Brewer Down the Street
international_trade_points.trade_description: Much of the craft brewery boom's appeal to consumers was, and remains, the ability to visit the brewery in-person, get a tour or just enjoy on-site drinks and games with friends.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Globalization Increases Domestic Exposure to International Brands
international_trade_points.trade_description: Foreign craft beer movements are piquing Americans' interest. Swedish breweries are creating innovative styles, like organic beers, that satisfy domestic consumers' evolving taste preferences and quench the desire for a varied beer fridge.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Craft Exports Tumble Amid a Tumultuous Period
international_trade_points.trade_description: Craft breweries struggle to market their products effectively overseas, as many lack the means and connections to do so affordably. As a result, exports have historically accounted for a small share of revenue.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Favorable Trade Policies Facilitate Cross-Border Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) promotes trade between the countries, with craft beer most often arriving in Canada, which accounts for nearly a third of all industry exports.

business_locations.location_description: The West's popularity among craft breweries stems from its vibrant beer culture, ideal climate and diverse consumer base. With its large population and robust economy, California serves as a hub for craft beer innovation and growth.
The Southeast region is a burgeoning area for craft breweries, driven by a growing demand for unique beer experiences, a rich culinary history and a sense of Southern hospitality.
The Great Lakes region, spearheaded by Michigan, thrives as a craft beer haven, thanks to its abundance of freshwater sources, agrarian resources, and a dedicated craft beer community.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Each state has its own set of ABC laws that regulate the sale and distribution of alcohol. These rules can differ widely, affecting everything from licensing fees to permitted distribution methods. In states like California, breweries navigate a more liberal framework allowing direct-to-consumer sales, while in places like New Jersey, regulations are stricter and often include limitations on the number of events a brewery can host.

regulations_points.regulation_title: US ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO TAX AND TRADE BUREAU (TTB)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The TTB regulates the production, distribution and taxation of beer. Craft breweries must obtain a federal brewing permit from the TTB before beginning operations. This involves rigorous documentation and background checks. The bureau also imposes excise taxes, which vary based on production volume.

The three-tier distribution system separates producers, distributors and retailers into three layers. This often means craft breweries can only sell directly to retailers or consumers by adhering to specific conditions or acquiring special licenses.
Before a brewery can sell its beer, TTB approval is required for each label. This ensures that labels aren't misleading and meet specific criteria.
Craft breweries must comply with OSHA standards, ensuring a safe workplace. Breweries deal with chemicals, pressurized systems and heavy machinery with substantial risks.

As environmental concerns grow, breweries are increasingly subject to regulations concerning water usage, waste disposal and emissions. The EPA (Environmental Protection Agency) enforces wastewater discharge and air quality rules.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The Three-Tier System challenges many craft breweries, often needing more financial resources to secure cost-effective distributor contracts.

Due to local, small-scale operations, craft beer production is more accessible for new entrants. Essential brewing equipment can be purchased relatively cheaply, enabling new brewers to start their ventures without significant upfront investment.

basis_points.basis_description: New entrants to craft beer production face a saturated market. Brewers distinguish themselves by developing appealing brand identities and diversifying their product lines.
Craft brewers need substantial capital investment for essential equipment such as boil kettles, mash tuns, fermenters, bottling systems and sanitizing equipment.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The Nature of Craft Limits Breweries' Reach
concentration_points.concentration_description: To be considered a craft brewer in the United States, producers can, at most, have an annual production of 6 million barrels of beer.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Craft's Popularity Attracts a Flood of New Breweries
concentration_points.concentration_description: Despite the challenges faced by breweries over the past five years, new producers have continued to flood the market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The cost of raw materials such as malted barley, hops and yeast often varies due to the inherently volatile nature of commodity prices.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Craft brewers need substantial capital investment for essential equipment such as boil kettles, mash tuns, fermenters, bottling systems and sanitizing equipment.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE CRAFT BOOM IS FIZZLING OUT
volatility_points.volatility_description: Craft breweries experienced explosive growth in the 2010s when consumer preferences for higher-margin local brews began to flourish.
Inflationary pressures and economic uncertainty are dragging down craft beer sales.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: HOPS FANATICISM DRIVES MORE HEAVILY-FLAVORED BEERS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Increasing preferences for hoppy beers and more robust flavors are forcing brewers to get creative.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: RISING HEALTH CONSCIOUSNESS BOOSTS NONALCOHOLIC BEER
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: A rise in health consciousness is fueling growth in nonalcoholic beer.

FAQs.question: While exports struggle to gain significant traction, do rising imports represent significant competition for your brewery?
FAQs.answer: Operators experience continual competition from international brands, as consumers enjoy trying different types and styles of beer and generally perceive these varieties to be of higher quality.

FAQs.question: What role do festivals play for smaller breweries?
FAQs.answer: Festivals give smaller breweries immense exposure to thousands of potential customers, significantly boosting their visibility and sales.

FAQs.question: How does The Brewer's Association (BA) support craft breweries in the US?
FAQs.answer: The BA is a vital lifeline for many craft breweries in the US. This national organization provides many resources, including educational seminars, market data and legislative advocacy.

FAQs.question: What are the benefits of industry conferences and trade shows for craft breweries?
FAQs.answer: Industry-specific conferences and trade shows provide craft breweries with invaluable opportunities to network, learn and collaborate.

FAQs.question: Although they account for a small share of revenue, have exports provided a meaningful market for your company?
FAQs.answer: While demand for domestic craft brews is present in international markets, it is relatively tame compared with domestic markets.

FAQs.question: Where does your company garner the most revenue from?
FAQs.answer: Craft brewers largely serve their customers through in-house bars and tasting rooms, along with downstream on-premise establishments.

FAQs.question: Do revenue losses amid times of economic certainty disrupt expansion plans?
FAQs.answer: When operators struggle amid economic uncertainty, expansion plans are often put on hold.

FAQs.question: Amid revenue and profit declines, has your brewery sought to reduce wage costs through automated processes?
FAQs.answer: While some operators might consider this, many craft brewers pride themselves on their intimate production processes.

FAQs.question: Has your company reduced overall production costs through advances in inventory management technologies?
FAQs.answer: Technologies used to distribute and keep track of beer products are constantly evolving, indirectly boosting the industry.

FAQs.question: Do retaliatory tariffs placed on many domestic alcoholic beverages by foreign markets impact your company's international distribution?
FAQs.answer: While most craft beers are often spared from significant tariffs, exports have historically accounted for a small share of revenue.

FAQs.question: Have any regulations significantly inhibited your business's operations?
FAQs.answer: Regulations like excise taxes, labeling requirements and limits on the types of beer that can be produced have inhibited operations of craft beer.

FAQs.question: How does profit vary across the craft beer industry?
FAQs.answer: Profit varies significantly, depending on an operator's size, scope and locations.

FAQs.question: How does input price volatility impact the industry's profit?
FAQs.answer: The average industry operator endures profit declines amid input price volatility.

FAQs.question: How important is branding for success in the craft beer industry?
FAQs.answer: Successful branding is critical to success in a brand-competitive market.

FAQs.question: How extensive is your distribution network? Do you generally serve a niche, local market or are you distributed across state lines?
FAQs.answer: New entrants must have access to distribution networks to get their beer sold at restaurants, bars and other retail locations.

FAQs.question: Due to the popularity of seasonal beer varieties, do you experience heightened demand during certain periods of the year?
FAQs.answer: Operators generally experience heightened demand during warmer seasons of the year.

FAQs.question: Do rises in expenditure on alcohol amid economic uncertainty assist your company in weathering declining revenue?
FAQs.answer: While a rise in expenditure may assist some operators, it largely depends on their distribution networks.

FAQs.question: Has the decline in the TWI presented an opportunity for your company to expand into international markets? How much of your company's sales are derived from exports?
FAQs.answer: Exports have historically accounted for a miniscule share of industry revenue.

FAQs.question: How has swelling competition from distilleries affected your company's performance?
FAQs.answer: Increased demand from distilleries generally translates to weakened demand for industry products.
